text:
Use the long division algorithm to write each fraction as a decimal.

Which fractions terminate and which ones repeat? Explain your thinking.

• 1/3 = 0.33… Repeating
  • ¼ = 0.25
  • 1/5 = 0.2
  • 1/6 = 0.166… Repeating
  • 1/7 = 0.142857142857… Repeating
  • 1/8 = 0.125
  • 1/9 = 0.11… Repeating
  • 1/10 = 0.1
  • 1/11 = 0.090909… Repeating

The fractions whose denominators have only factors of 2 and 5 terminate.

All the others repeat (1/3, 1/6, 1/7, 1/9, and 1/11).

One reason is that numbers whose prime factors are 2 and/or 5 can be written as multiples of 10. So fractions with denominators 2, 4, 5, 8, 10, 16, 20 , … will terminate. All others will repeat.
DeAndre claims he can use his results from the preceding questions to write each of the following as decimals without using long division. Is this possible? Explain.
Nevaeh claims she can predict whether each of the following fractions will have a decimal representation that terminates or repeats. Is this possible? Explain.

Repeating: 5/7 = 0.714285714285…, 8/9 = 0.88..., 4/3 = 1.333…

Note that repeating decimals can be indicated by ellipsis (1.333…) or by a “repeating bar".

Terminating: 1/16 = 0.0625, 3/5 = 0.6, 13/10 = 1.3, 11/5 = 2.2

The denominators of the fractions that represent the terminating decimals have a prime factorization that contains 2 and/or 5.
